fields.headline: Gary Husband/Alex Machacek: Now – review
fields.bodyText: Gary Husband, the British maverick virtuoso who plays mercurial postbop piano and jazz-rock drums (formerly with Level 42 and latterly with John McLaughlin's 4th Dimension), has taken a reflective musical journey here, playing piano in a delicate duo with Austrian guitarist Alex Machacek. The latter flies through fast passages with a Django Reinhardt-like lightness, and plays ballads with a caressing, jazz-guitar purr, and Husband stays so close to him he seems like an alter ego – sometimes adopting an almost Ellingtonesque swing in the fast contrapuntal passages, and often improvising with a fluency that recalls Chick Corea (who writes an unqualified eulogy to this music in the artwork). Some tracks have a beboppish drive; there are rapturous ballads penetrated by Machacek's singing, single-note sound; a little ambient mistiness; and even a bluegrass-influenced tune that soon turns funky. Some episodes are rather whimsical, but it's all very elegantly played, and the slow-building but eventually ecstatic Spring Song is a standout.
